resources.string: Just your email and a password â€” quick and easy.
Weâ€™ll use it to cheer you on during your workouts!
Tell us your weight and height so we can tailor your plan.
No worries â€” weâ€™ve got plans for every level.
Pick muscle groups you donâ€™t want to train. Totally optional!
Weâ€™ll leave out exercises that need that equipment.
This will help us personalize your workout recommendations.
Used for calculating stats like BMI and optimizing your workouts.
You've been working out for less than 1 year and are currently getting familiar with the exercises.
You've been working out for over 1 year, are familiar with most exercises, and have developed a solid base.
You've been working out for over 2 years, have good exercise form, and show consistent physical progress.
You've been working out for over 5 years, have excellent exercise form, and maintain a high level of muscular development.
Closing now will cause all your progress in this session to be lost.
You have an unfinished training session. Continue where you left off?

Total work per exercise (weight Ã— reps); shows which lifts contributed most today.
Tip: Volume rewards high-rep/light sets; check %1RM/Intensity to see how heavy it was.
Targets: Advanced ~Â±10â€“15% vs last comparable session; Novice/Intermediate Â±15â€“25%.
Avoid spikes: >20â€“30% unless you are peaking.
After a break: resume ~10% lower and add ~10% per session for a week.

Total work per day; compare to your rolling 7-day average.
Targets: Advanced ~Â±10â€“15%; Novice/Intermediate Â±15â€“25% day-to-day.
Spikes: avoid >20â€“30% unless planned; light days (âˆ’20â€“40%) aid recovery.
After time off: add ~10% per session in week 1.
Use small waves (hard/medium/light) for sustainable progress.

Total work per week inside this month.
Progression: grow ~5â€“10% WoW for 2â€“4 weeks, then deload 20â€“40%.
Balance: keep the heaviest week <~40â€“50% of the monthâ€™s total to avoid overreaching.
Signals: if volume climbs but performance stalls, deload or improve sleep/nutrition.
Plan: place hard weeks when life stress is lower; deload before testing/new blocks.

Zoomed-out monthly trend across the year.
Structure: plan 3â€“5 progressive blocks with clear deloads.
Safety: avoid month-to-month spikes >~30â€“40%; prefer steady growth.
Expectations: YoY gains of ~10â€“30% are realistic depending on training age.
If PRs lag while volume rises, shift work toward main lifts or increase intensity modestly.

Each cell shows Î£(weightÃ—reps) credited to a muscle, allocated by exercise muscle splits.
Normalization: per-column max (colors are relative within this session; columns are not comparable).
Use when you care about total load distribution across muscles in this session.
Notes: Tonnage favors high-rep/light sets; pair with intensity charts for context.
Gaps mean no work recorded for that muscle in that exercise bucket.

Each cell shows Î£(reps) credited to a muscle via exercise muscle splits (weight ignored).
Normalization: per-column max (relative within this session only).
Best for bodyweight/isolation work and technique volume.
Limit: treats all reps equally; heavy triples and easy fifteens look similar.
Use with %1RM/Intensity for a complete picture.

Cells show Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle for each day in range.
Normalization: per-column max (relative per day; do not compare colors across days).
Look for balanced coverage of big movers (quads, hamstrings, back, chest).
Spikes highlight days dominated by a few muscles; plan lighter coverage next day if recovery lags.

Cells show Î£(reps) per muscle for each day; weight ignored.
Normalization: per-column max (relative per day).
Great for tracking bodyweight or accessory emphasis.
If a target muscle stays near zero across days, add direct work.

Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle per week inside this month view.
Normalization: per-column max (relative per week; colors across weeks are not directly comparable).
Use to see which weeks emphasized which muscles; follow heavy weeks with easier ones.
Persistent near-zero rows suggest undertrained muscles.

Î£(reps) per muscle per week; weight ignored.
Normalization: per-column max (relative per week).
Good for specialty blocks and bodyweight phases.
Add intensity checks if reps climb without strength progress.

Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle per month.
Normalization: global cap at P95 (extremes clipped; colors are comparable across months).
Read trends across months: specialization blocks should visibly raise the target row.
If volume rises but PRs stall, shift work from accessories to main lifts or increase intensity modestly.

Î£(reps) per muscle per month; weight ignored.
Normalization: global cap at P95 (comparable across months).
Great for long technique or hypertrophy phases.
Plateaus with high reps often mean intensity is too low â€” add heavier work.

Year-to-date Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle (monthly buckets).
Normalization: global cap at P95 (comparable across months).
Look for 3â€“5 progressive blocks and clear deloads; avoid persistent imbalance (e.g., pushâ‰«pull).
Large gaps suggest injury/time off or program drift â€” rebalance accordingly.

Year-to-date Î£(reps) per muscle.
Normalization: global cap at P95 (comparable across months).
Useful to audit total practice volume per muscle group.
If reps are high but strength stagnant, blend in lower-rep, higher-load work.

Each bar shows total work Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle or group.
Color scale: smooth by share vs session max (darker = more work).
Tip: Volume rewards high-rep/light sets; pair with intensity charts for context.
Auto mode: if no meaningful weights are entered today, the view will switch to Reps.

Each bar shows total repetitions Î£(reps) credited to a muscle via exercise splits (weight ignored).
Color scale: smooth by share vs session max.
Best for bodyweight/isolation work and technique volume.
If heavy sets exist, consider switching to Volume for load context.

Bars show Î£(repsÃ—sec/rep) per muscle using a fixed tempo.\nColor scale: smooth by share vs session max.\nGood proxy when weights vary widely between exercises; verify tempo really matches your sets.
Muscle Load â€” Session (% of Total, Volume)
Bars show each muscleâ€™s share of Î£(weightÃ—reps) within the session (100% total).\nColor scale: banded by percent.\nUse to compare balance across muscles today regardless of absolute workload.
Muscle Load â€” Session (% of Total, Reps)
Bars show each muscleâ€™s share of Î£(reps) within the session (100% total).\nColor scale: banded by percent.\nUseful when weights are missing or mostly bodyweight.
Muscle Load â€” Session (% of Total, TUT)
Bars show share of Î£(repsÃ—sec/rep) within the session (100% total).\nColor scale: banded by percent.\nUse when tempo is consistent across exercises.
Muscle Load â€” Days (% of Total, Volume)

Share of Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle across selected days (adds to 100%).\nColor scale: banded by percent; bars are comparable across items.\nGoal: big movers (quads, hamstrings, back, chest) should receive meaningful shares; avoid leaving target muscles <10â€“15% week after week.
Muscle Load â€” Days (% of Total, Reps)
Share of Î£(reps) per muscle across selected days (100% total).\nUseful when many sets lack weights or are bodyweight.\nIf shares look fine but strength stalls, add heavier work to main lifts.
Muscle Load â€” Days (% of Total, TUT)
Share of Î£(repsÃ—sec/rep) per muscle across days.\nGood for tempo-driven phases; ensure tempo is consistent to keep comparisons fair.
Muscle Load â€” Weeks (% of Total, Volume)
Share of weekly Î£(weightÃ—reps) by muscle (100% within the selected month).\nLook for clear emphasis weeks, followed by easier weeks.\nPersistent near-zero rows suggest undertrained muscles.
Muscle Load â€” Weeks (% of Total, Reps)
Share of weekly Î£(reps) by muscle.\nUse for bodyweight blocks and technique phases; complement with intensity checks.
Muscle Load â€” Weeks (% of Total, TUT)
Share of weekly Î£(repsÃ—sec/rep) by muscle.\nHelps compare slow-tempo blocks; verify consistency of tempo in logging.
Muscle Load â€” Months (% of Total, Volume)

Share of Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle by month (adds to 100%).\nTrack specialization blocks: the target muscle should visibly gain share.\nIf volume share rises but PRs stall, shift work toward main lifts or raise intensity modestly.
Muscle Load â€” Months (% of Total, Reps)
Share of Î£(reps) per muscle by month.\nGreat for long technique/hypertrophy phases.\nPlateaus with high rep share usually mean intensity is too low â€” add heavier work.
Muscle Load â€” Months (% of Total, TUT)
Share of Î£(repsÃ—sec/rep) per muscle by month.\nUseful when load tracking is noisy; keep tempo realistic for fair comparisons.
Muscle Load â€” Year (% of Total, Volume)
Year-to-date share of Î£(weightÃ—reps) per muscle (100% over the year).\nSeek 3â€“5 progressive blocks with deloads; avoid chronic pushâ‰«pull or quadâ‰«posterior chain imbalances.
Muscle Load â€” Year (% of Total, Reps)
Year-to-date share of Î£(reps) per muscle.\nGood to audit practice volume.\nIf rep share is high but strength lags, blend in lower-rep, higher-load work.
Muscle Load â€” Year (% of Total, TUT)
Year-to-date share of Î£(repsÃ—sec/rep) per muscle.\nHandy for tempo phases; confirm logging stays consistent over months.

Best strength estimate per exercise today from your sets and repsâ€”no need to test a true max. Small PRs of about +0.5â€“2.5% are meaningful; a flat trend or âˆ’2â€“5% is common during high-volume phases.
Near-max strength for each day. Do not chase a PR every session; a few strong days per week are enough. If daily peaks dip slightly (around âˆ’2â€“5%) while volume is high, thatâ€™s normal.
Best or near-best sets each week across the month. Aim for gradual improvement of about +0.5â€“2% month over month. Short dips during deload weeks are expected.

Peak or near-peak strength across the year. A realistic goal is +1â€“5% per year depending on training level. Long plateaus can happenâ€”stay patient, cycle volume and intensity, and focus on technique.
